A ring (admitting a unit element) is a set R together with two laws of composition written as addition '+' and multiplication '.' such that: (i) R is a commutative group with respect to addition. (ii) R is a monoid with respect to multiplication, i.e., the multiplication is associative, and there exists a unit element in R. (iii) The distributive laws hold, i.e., (a+b) 
cdot c=a 
cdot c+b 
cdot c, and c 
cdot(a+b)=c 
cdot a+c 
cdot b for all a, b, c in R.
A family (x_i)_{i in I} of elements of an A-module M is called a system of generators of M if M = sum_{i in I} A x_i.
Does the concept of a/an Ring need to be defined for a definition of a/an System of generators to make sense? (True if the first concept is needed and False if is not.)

Explanation: The definition of a System of generators involves a family of elements from an A-module M. An A-module, by definition, is a structure where the elements can be scaled by elements from a ring A. This means that the concept of a ring is fundamental to the definition of an A-module, as the ring provides the scalars used in the module operations.\n\nSince a System of generators is defined within the context of an A-module, and an A-module inherently requires a ring (as it consists of elements that are scaled by elements of a ring), the concept of a ring must be defined and understood first. Without the concept of a ring, the definition of an A-module, and consequently the definition of a System of generators, would not make sense. Therefore, the concept of a ring is necessary for the definition of a System of generators to be meaningful.
